title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Subchapter I of chapter 73 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new section on Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary shall organize the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined networks aligned with the Department's mission and specific healthcare requirements of veterans. Each network must implement national goals and maintain a regional integrated healthcare system. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by implementing alliances with other healthcare organizations, managing a regional budget, using national metrics for efficient healthcare delivery, and ensuring high-quality clinical programs and services. The Secretary ensures effective, efficient, and safe delivery of healthcare, high-quality clinical programs, reduction of duplicate functions, collaboration, and cooperation within the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary works to achieve maximum effectiveness in patient care, graduate medical education, and research. They assess the consolidation or realignment of institutional functions in collaboration with other entities within the geographical area of the Network, including offices of the Veterans Benefits Administration, Department of Defense, Coast Guard, and State and local agencies assisting veterans. The Secretary ensures coordination with various offices including Coast Guard, State and local agencies assisting veterans, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community organizations, and other federal offices. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks are required to develop and share innovations and best practices. Each network is mandated to have only one headquarters office. The Secretary ensures coordination with various offices to assist veterans at local, regional, and national levels. Each Veterans Integrated Service Network is mandated to have only one headquarters office co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The Secretary may employ up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors at each headquarters. Annual reports on employment at the headquarters of Veterans Integrated Service Networks are submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The annual report includes the number of individuals employed at each headquarters of a Veterans Integrated Service Network, their titles, and an assessment of the impact on the Department's budget. Additionally, a triennial review is conducted every three years to reassess the structure and report on the employment situation. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting a report with recommendations to improve them to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining various networks into single entities to comply with section 7309(a) of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the Act's enactment. This involves combining multiple networks into single entities to comply with section 7309(a) of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single entities to comply with section 7309(a) of the title. This involves combining networks and headquarters to meet the requirements of the Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate headquarters offices to comply with the Act, finding new positions for affected individuals within the Department of Veterans Affairs. A plan for implementation must be submitted to the relevant committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks to comply with co-location requirements. If a lease is renewed or a new lease is entered into, a report must be submitted. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks to comply with co-location requirements. If a lease is renewed or a new lease is entered into, a report must be submitted detailing underutilized buildings, costs of the current lease, and square footage being leased. The report must detail underutilized buildings and the costs of the current lease, including annual rent, total cost over the lease life, and cost per square foot. It should also include the cost of the new lease and the square footage to be leased. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary will establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. These centers will assess finance operations, compliance activities, and outreach efforts to veterans who served in specific military operations. The Veterans Integrated Service Network conducts outreach to veterans who served in specific military operations and assesses programs for women veterans, homelessness among veterans, energy consumption, and other relevant matters. The Secretary may hire employees and contractors for regional support centers. The Secretary establishes regional support centers co-located with VA medical centers, unless approved by committees. Report required for non-co-located centers, listing underutilized VA buildings. The report must list underutilized VA buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, including total square footage and lease costs for regional support centers. Initial staffing for these centers involves transferring employees from headquarters to cover similar functions. The report requires transferring employees from VA headquarters to regional support centers to cover similar functions as outlined in section 7309A(b) of the title. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 73 of the title. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not mandate any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
